White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders stressed during a press conference that Manafort’s alleged illegal activities had nothing to do with the campaign and said that George Papadopoulos—a Trump campaign adviser who pleaded guilty to making false statements to the FBI about his 2016 contact with people purporting to represent the Russian government—was a campaign volunteer.

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan largely avoided saying anything about the news, at first saying he didn’t want to speculate on something he hadn’t read and then said he had “nothing to add, other than nothing’s going to derail what we’re doing in Congress.”

Advertisement



House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy said in response to Monday's news that he believed the election had nothing to do with Russian interference.

Grassley had previously complained the law was not enforced well enough, according to the AP, and he said “it should be enforced fairly and consistently, regardless of politics or any other factor.”

One of the first responses from a member of the GOP came from Indiana Rep. Jim Banks, who declared support for the Mueller investigation.

Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley, the Republican chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, reacted by praising the DOJ for enforcing the Foreign Agents Registration Act, which requires agents of foreign governments register with the United States, according to the Associated Press.

https://t.co/Iukg1Gbj8s — Nancy Pelosi (@TeamPelosi) October 30, 2017

And Sen. Richard Blumenthal, a member of the Judiciary Committee, called the indictment a “major step toward answers and accountability.”

Strong bipartisan support for Special Counsel now critical.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said there was still a need for an “outside, fully independent investigation.”

RETWEET if you agree: we *still* need an outside, #IndependentCommission to fully uncover the Trump-Russia collusion in our elections.

Rep. Adam Kinzinger of Illinois also tweeted a comment supporting Mueller's investigation.

On the Democrat side, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer warned Trump against interfering with the special counsel’s work.
"I don't believe Russia did anything to influence whether Trump got elected or not from the basis that the American people decided."
The president tweeted Monday, “Sorry, but this is years ago, before Paul Manafort was part of the Trump campaign.
As I’ve said from day one, the American people deserve answers, transparency & the truth.
The rule of law is paramount in America & the investigation must proceed unimpeded.
"I think Russia meddles in everyone's election," he told CNBC.
The special counsel’s probe is ongoing in a serious way.
But why aren’t Crooked Hillary & the Dems the focus????

?”

He continued, “....Also, there is NO COLLUSION!”
We must come together behind the rule of law.
Important to allow Mueller to do his job.
